Name: Scholarly Ontology
Description: An ontology for modeling scholarly practices, based on notions from business process modelling and Cultural-Historical Activity Theory.

Name: Ontology for Linked Open University Data
Description: The objectives of the OLOUD ontology is to support the development and publishing of Linked Open University Datasets and the applications built on the top of these Open Datasets. OLOUD contains classes and properties to describe Organizations, People, their Roles and Publications, Subjects, Courses and other Events and their temporal and spatial description. The ontology is divided into two connected modules: 1. OLOUD-BASE is the main module describing all the university related concepts and uses the prefix oloud, 2. OLOUD-LOC module provides the indoor location and navigation features and uses the prefix loc.

Name: Ontology for Linked Open University Data
Description: This ontology provides indoor location and navigation features. An extension of OLOUD-BASE

Name: VIVO-ISF Ontology
Description: An ontology of academic and research domain, developed in the framework of the VIVO project

Name: Semantic Web for Research Communities
Description: An ontology for modeling entities of research communities such as persons, organisations, publications (bibliographic metadata) and their relationship

Name: Ontology for Academic Program Accreditation
Description: Ontology of Accreditation Board of Engineering and Technology(ABET) Process

Name: Curriculum, Course, and Syllabus Ontology
Description: This Ontology aims to provide data model for describing the subjects of Curriculum, Course and Syllabus in Higher education.

Name: FOAF-Academic Ontology
Description: A Vocabulary for the Academic Community.

Name: Academic Institution Internal Structure Ontology
Description: The Academic Institution Internal Structure Ontology (AIISO) provides classes and properties to describe the internal organizational structure of an academic institution.

Name: Education Standards Ontology
Description: Education Standards Ontology

Name: Education Application Ontology
Description: Education Application Ontology

Name: Funding, Research Administration and Projects Ontology
Description: The Funding, Research Administration and Projects Ontology, is a CERIF-compliant ontology written in OWL 2 DL for describing research project administrative information.

Name: PLET4Thesis
Description: Designed in order to organise the process of thesis development using the elements required to create a PLE (personal leaning environment).  Designed to guide thesis students in the construction of their PLE.

Name: Open Research Knowledge Graph
Description: Used for Comparing Research Contributions in a Scholarly Knowledge Graph

Name: Researcher Profile Ontology
Description: Designed specifically to represent academic contexts at a public university.

Name: Informatics Research Artifacts Ontology
Description: Used to describe research artifacts in research, including authorship, evolution, etc.

Name: Scholarly Event Description Ontology
Description: An ontology for scholarly event description.

Name: Ontology for Academic Department
Description: This ontology help people in an academic department to mark up their metadata of resources.

Name: AcademIS
Description: AcademIS: an ontology for representing academic activity and collaborations within HEIs

Name: The Computer Science Ontology
Description: The Computer Science Ontology (CSO) is a large-scale ontology of research areas that was automatically generated using the Klink-2 algorithm on the Rexplore dataset, which consists of about 16 million publications, mainly in the field of Computer Science.

Name: Bibontology
Description: The Bibliographic Ontology Specification provides main concepts and properties for describing citations and bibliographic references (i.e. quotes, books, articles, etc) on the Semantic Web.

Name: SemSur
Description: A Core Ontology for the Semantic Representation of Research Findings for describing individual research problems, approaches, implementations and evaluations in a structured, comparable way

Name: Research Object Ontology
Description: Provides basic structure for the description of aggregated resources and the annotations that are made on those resources.

Name: The Common European Research Information Format Ontology
Description: The Common European Research Information Format (CERIF) Ontology Specification provides basic concepts and properties for describing research information as semantic data. This document contains a friendly description of the Common European Research Information Format (CERIF) Ontology developed by EuroCRIS.

Name: FRBR-aligned Bibliographic Ontology
Description: FaBiO is an ontology for describing entities that are published or potentially publishable (such as journal articles, conference papers, books), and that contain or are referred to by bibliographic references. It also includes blogs, web pages, data sets, computer algorithms, experimental protocols, formal specifications and vocabularies, legal records, governmental papers, technical and commercial reports, and similar publications, and also anthologies, catalogs, and similar collections. FaBiO has been developed so to limit any restriction to its classes also because of the domains and ranges of its properties. FaBiO has flexibility and it has a good advantage of allowing FaBiO to be used alongside other models.

Name: Citation Typing Ontology
Description: CiTO is an ontology that permits characterization of the character or sort of citations, both factually and rhetorically. Properties (and, consequently, their inverses) could also be classified as rhetorical and/or factual, with the rhetorical properties being grouped in three sets counting on their connotation: positive, informative (neutral) or negative. For the domain and range constraints from the thing, properties aren't defined, in order that this ontology might be easily integrated with other models, such as FaBiO. Two other ontologies are defined for explicitly describing specific aspects of CiTO. The primary one is named Functions of Citations Ontology (FOCO) and therefore the other called CiTO to Wordnet Ontology (C2W).

Name: Bibliographic Reference Ontology
Description: BiRO is an ontology meant to define bibliographic records, bibliographic references, and their compilation into bibliographic collections and bibliographic lists, respectively. It uses an OWL-based definition of the FRBR model to define bibliographic references and their compilation into ordered bibliographic lists, by means of the Collections Ontology.

Name: Citation Counting and Context Characterisation Ontology
Description: C4O is an ontology that allows the amount of in-text citations of a cited source to be recorded, alongside their textual citation contexts, alongside the number of citations a cited entity has received globally on a specific date. it's also useful to explain how these references are utilized in the citing paper. C4O also provides the ontological structures which permit one to record the amount of in-text citations like, the amount of in-text reference tips that could one reference within the reference list of the citing article.

Name: Document Components Ontology
Description: DoCO is an ontology that gives a structured vocabulary written of document components, both structural (such as, block, inline, paragraph, section, chapter) and rhetorical (such as, introduction, discussion, acknowledgments, reference list, figure, appendix). It imports the Pattern Ontology that describes structural patterns, and therefore the Discourse Element Ontology (DEO), which was developed with DoCO and describes rhetorical components. It also defines hybrid classes describing elements that are both structural and rhetorical in nature, like paragraph, section, or list. DoCO is additionally aligned with the SALT Rhetorical Ontology and therefore the Ontology of Rhetorical Blocks (ORB).

Name: Publishing Status Ontology
Description: PSO is an ontology designed to characterize the publication status of documents at each stage of the publishing process (such as draft, submitted, under review, etc.). Documents can hold a specific status at a specific time as an immediate consequence of a particular event. Pre Existing ontologies describing the status of documents (such as, BIBO, the Project Documents Ontology, and therefore the Document Status Ontology), relay for this on specific property links but this approach prevents a correct description of scenarios that need a temporal duration for every status. it's been developed so as to deal with these issues in a more satisfactory manner. With PRO, PSO was developed following the TVC pattern, such as, a model for describing scenarios during which something has value during a specific time and for a specific context.

Name: Publishing Roles Ontology
Description: PRO is an ontology for the characterization of the roles of agents â€“ people, corporate bodies, and computational agents within the publication process. These agents are often, authors, editors, reviewers, publishers, or librarians. Define publishing roles is crucial for providing an entire description of a scholarly resource like a paper or a dataset. Using TVC pattern, a model for describing scenarios during which something has value during a specific time and for a specific context because the basis, they need to implement PRO, the Publishing Roles Ontology.

Name: Publishing Workflow Ontology
Description: PWO, a simple ontology for describing the steps of the workflow related to the publication of a document or other publication entity. PWO supported two main classes called Workflow and Step.

Name: Scholarly Contributions and Roles Ontology
Description: SCoRO is the Scholarly Contributions and Roles Ontology (CERIF-compliant ontology), used by authors, publishers, and research administrators, for describing the contributions and roles of students, and therefore the organizations of which they're members, with reference to projects, research investigations, and other academic activities, and to the scholarly journal articles and other outputs that result from them.

Name: Funding, Research Administration and Projects Ontology
Description: FRAPO is that the Funding, Research Administration and Projects Ontology, which may be a CERIF-compliant ontology for describing administrative information concerning grant funding and research projects. It is often used for the characterization of grant applications, funding bodies, research projects, project partners, etc., in other words, the type of data stored in Current Research Information Systems (CRIS). It also can be wont to describe other sorts of projects, for instance, building projects and academic projects. It also imports FOAF for characterizing people.

Name: DataCite Ontology
Description: The main intent of the DataCite Ontology is to supply a versatile mechanism to define the identifier for bibliographic resources (papers and datasets) and related entities. it's also possible to supply a link between a resource, like a dataset, and therefore the document describing its metadata by means of CiTO, using the property citesAsMetadataDocument, and FaBiO, by means of the category MetadataDocument. additionally, to those entities, the DataCite Ontology provides appropriate classes and properties to specify the actual scheme followed for creating the resource metadata exemplified within the metadata document.

Name: Bibliometric Data Ontology
Description: BiDO developed a well-known model for enabling the classification of authors and journals consistent with bibliometric data is crucial to permit one to question, share and reuse such data during a different context, for example, for providing smart visualization of bibliometric data for sense-making activities and for enabling automatic reasoning on them. The core module of the ontology allows us to explain any entity and therefore the related bibliometric data at a particular time and consistent with a particular agent. BiDO consists of three different modules and people are Standard bibliometric measures, Research career categories, and Review measures.

Name: Five Stars of Online Research Articles Ontology
Description: Peer review, open access, enriched content, available datasets, and machine-readable metadata are the core components of the Five Stars of Online Journal Articles, a constellation of the five independent criteria within a multi-dimensional publishing universe against which online journal articles are often evaluated, to ascertain how well they match up with current visions for enhanced research communications. These Five Stars of Online Journal Articles provide a conceptual framework by which to gauge the degree to which any article achieves or falls in need of the perfect, which should be useful to authors, editors, and publishers.

Name: FAIR* Reviews Ontology
Description: FAIR* is a review Ontology (FR) that defines a group of classes, properties, and axioms, for describing research reviews as semantic objects, reusing standard existing vocabularies using ontology engineering techniques.

Name: Extension of the BiDO Ontology to Represent Scientific Production
Description: BSBM is an extension of the BiDO Ontology, particularly to BiDO Standard Bibliometric Measures.

Name: OpenCitations
Description: The OpenCitations Data Model (OCDM) is the metadata model used for the info stored altogether the OpenCitation datasets. OCDM also allows one to record information about: published bibliographic resources, possible resource embodiments, bibliographic references, responsible agents, roles, citations, external identifiers.
